See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sentinel_Building_(Centralia,_Illinois) "The Sentinel Building is a historic building located at 232 East Broadway in Centralia, Illinois. The building was constructed in 1881 to serve as the headquarters and printing press of the Centralia Sentinel, Centralia's daily newspaper. Renovations in 1922 and 1929 converted the building's design to the Egyptian Revival style; the change reflected the Sentinel's slogan, "Egypt's Greatest Daily", which was chosen since the newspaper served the Little Egypt region." 232 East Broadway, Centralia, Illinois. 2024 Streetview

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plan_9_from_Outer_Space "Plan 9 from Outer Space is a 1957 American independent science fiction-horror film produced, written, directed, and edited by Ed Wood. The film was shot in black-and-white in November 1956 and had a preview screening on March 15, 1957, at the Carlton Theatre in Los Angeles under the title Grave Robbers from Outer Space. Retitled Plan 9 from Outer Space, it went into general release in July 1958 in Virginia, Texas and several other Southern states, before being sold to television in 1961." There is a hand-written number 58-294 at lower right. Perhaps the poster was used for the July 1958 release. The color slide was made later.

This is not typical of the Bernard Gotfryd collection of photos, which is mainly portraits of people in the news and illustrations of newsworthy events, pictures taken when he was working on commissions for the magazine Newsweek. Gotfryd gave the photos to the Library of Congress but restricted digitization and public access until his death, which was in 2016. A large portion of the collection was made available for remote public access in June 2021. See: * Free to Use and Reuse: The Photographs of Bernard Gotfryd (June 16, 2021) blogs.loc.gov/loc/2021/06/free-to-use-and-reuse-the-photo... * Ready for Research: Newsmaker Photos by Bernard Gotfryd (June 3, 2021) blogs.loc.gov/picturethis/2021/06/ready-for-research-news... * Finding aid for Bernard Gotfryd collection hdl.loc.gov/loc.pnp/eadpnp.pp019004

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fox_Cave "Fox Cave is located on East Highway 70 between Roswell and Alamogordo, near Ruidoso, New Mexico. It was once used as a hideout by William H. Bonney, better known as Billy the Kid and also known as Henry Antrim, a 19th-century American gunman who participated in the Lincoln County War and became a frontier outlaw in the American Old West. Originally known as "Ice Cave" in the late 1800s and early 1900s, the rocks of Fox Cave are primarily micritic limestone. The cave was formed over thousands of years by erosion of the rock caused by the Ruidoso River." See also www.visitruidoso.com/fox-cave/ and 2024 Streetview of the outside of the cave

There was an Interchurch World Conference held in Atlantic City, NJ in January 1920. See, for example, The [Albuquerque] Evening Herald. January 07, 1920, page 1, middle of col 7. - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn92070582/1920-01-07/ed-... "Interchurch World Conference Opens ATLANTIC ClTY. N J.. Jan. 7 Nearly twenty protestant denominations are represented at the opening session today of the coordination conference of the Interchurch world movement. Nearly one thousand delegates were on hand when Dr. John R. Mott. general secretary of the Y. M. C, A., rapped for order. Among those in attendance are eleven bishops of the Methodist Episcopal church. Representing the Presbyterians are many heads of church boards and field workers in the new era movement. The primary object of the great conference is the coordinatlon of the expenditures of the protestant denominations with a view to avoiding waste and the overlapping of effort." This picture is probably of one delegation. Since there are 11 men, they could be from the Methodist Episcopal church.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Olga_Constantinovna_of_Russia "Olga Constantinovna of Russia (Greek: Όλγα; 3 September [O.S. 22 August] 1851 – 18 June 1926) was Queen of Greece as the wife of King George I. She was briefly the regent of Greece in 1920."

LoC has four pictures of Olga with negative numbers in sequence. They are probably four photographs of prints that were photographed by Bain at the same time. See www.loc.gov/pictures/related/?&pk=2014719569&st=g... She was Queen Consort of Greece from her marriage to George I of Greece in 1867 at the age of sixteen. In 1913, when she was 46, her husband was assassinated and she returned to Russia. It seems likely that the first three photos, at least, were taken in Greece before her husband was assassinated. The first and third photos look very much at the same age, although the dress and jewels are different. The second photo - www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/ggbain.50421/ indicates that it was taken by a photographer in Athens called "BOEHRINGER" According to nataliavogeikoff.com/2023/07/08/disjecta-membra-the-perso... "Carl Boehringer worked as a photographer in Athens in the late 19th/early 20th century. He held the unofficial title of the royal photographer because he had photographed members of the royal family."

The fourth photo of Olga in the Bain collection looks to be from later than the first three. www.instagram.com/michaelofgreece/p/CpqGRV8INs-/?img_index=1 indicates that she wore "widow's weeds" for the rest of her life. She died in 1926. See royalwatcherblog.com/2018/09/03/queen-olga-of-greece/ The best clue to the date of the original photographs I have found is: - www.gogmsite.net/new-content/1904-queen-olga-of-greece.html Other pictures with dates (that I haven't confirmed) are at: - www.gogmsite.net/russian-style-in-the-bustle/subalbum-gra...

Part of the patriotic Tableau at the City College Stadium 4th of July show. Julie Bradley Shipman portrayed either "Charity" or "The American Red Cross" depending which source you read. Lucien Muratore (a French Dramatic Tenor and actor) was there to sing "Le Marseillaise", without which no 4th of July celebration is complete. Mrs. Shipman was known as the wife of Rev. Herbert Shipman, rector of the Church of the Heavenly Rest (THE upper east side 5th Ave. Episcopal church) as well as the only child and heir of millionaire bourbon baron Edson Bradley. She managed to fit this 4th of July appearance into her Summer at Newport, where she and her husband took the Needwood Cottage for the season. There was more to the Shipmans than Society Teas. Rev. Shipman was also an Army chaplain. He spent 10 years as chaplain at West Point and in 1916 became chaplain to the NY National Guard's First Field Artillery during their deployment to the Mexican Border and as they became the 104th field artillery during WW1. He eventually became chaplain of the District of Paris, of the First Army Corps, and the whole Army Expeditionary Forces. Mrs Julie Shipman also didn't spend the war sitting a beach chair in Newport. During the winter she trained as a nurse and by January (fastest nursing training I've ever heard of) the papers were running lots of photos of her in a real nurse's uniform announcing that she would soon be going to tend the boys in France. (Spoiler - she did not) It might be nice to think that Julie Shipman is one of the nursing students in the Camp Wadsworth nursing school in this batch of Bain photos. Camp Wadsworth is where the Army sent all of the NY National Guard units for training and Rev. Wadsworth spent quite a few months there. But no, she supposedly did her training at NY Presbyterian hospital.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Georges_Carpentier "Georges Carpentier (French pronunciation: [ʒɔʁʒ kaʁ.pɑ̃ˈtje]; 12 January 1894 – 28 October 1975) was a French boxer, actor and World War I pilot. A precocious pugilist, Carpentier fought in numerous categories. He fought mainly as a light heavyweight and heavyweight in a career lasting from 1908 to 1926. A French professional champion on several occasions, he became the European heavyweight champion before the First World War. A sergeant aviator during the Great War, he was wounded before returning to civilian life. He then discovered rugby union, playing as a winger. On his return to the ring in 1919, "le grand Georges" ("the great Georges" in English) he was celebrated as a symbol of a sporting powerhouse France, via performances in Great Britain and the United States of America. His knockout victory over Battling Levinsky on 12 October 1920 in Jersey City in the United States earned him the title of world champion. A defeat by Jack Dempsey the following year nevertheless strengthened his legend and brought him worldwide fame."

Walter Damrosch (1862-1950) www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q725579

We've seen him before In 1920, in recognition of the NYSO's successful 8 week summer tour of Europe, Walter Damrosch was presented with a Golden Laurel Wreath. Or maybe 2 wreaths. Or maybe just one wreath presented twice. The New York Times reported in September that "The Musician's Club" presented the wreath to Damrosch on the day of his return to NYC on the Lafayette. The NY Trib and the NY Herald published similar stories in early November describing how Damrosch was presented with a Golden Wreath by the directors of the Symphony Society during a performance at Carnegie Hall. Did he get two wreaths 2 months apart? I suspect he was welcomed home with a/the wreath in September, but the formal presentation was made in November, giving him ample time to prepare his gracious extemporaneous remarks praising the president of the society (and funder of the trip). Given Damrosch's very formal attire in this photo, I would speculate that this dates from the November presentation, taken in a private room at Carnegie Hall.

At the beginning of 1917. a Handley-Page British plane, just from the factory, equipped with the newest type of Rolls-Royce motor and representing the most recent perfections achieved started across the Channel for France, but the pilot lost himself in a heavy fog, turned northward and landed within the German lines. Sylvia Tell was a ballerina with the Chicago Opera (performing first in late 1918) and then with the San Carlo Grand Opera. She also taught at the Cornish School of Fine Arts in Seattle. The details above were drawn from a number of sources: New-York Tribune. January 12, 1919, Image 48 - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1919-01-12/ed-... "Sylvia Tell is probably the youngest premiere danseuse in grand opera. A Chicago girl of Swiss parentage. She is only sixteen years of age. Her birthday and her debut occurred on the same date, November 18, the opening date of the Chicago season, when she became of legal age for public appearance." The Seattle Star. January 08, 1925, Image 9 - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87093407/1925-01-08/ed-... "Miss Sylvia Tell's ballet dancers from the Cornish School will appear with the San Carlo grand opera at the Metropolitan, January 20 and 24. ... Miss Tell, who started studying dancing as a child of 12 under an European instructor, did so mainly to help a delicate constitution. She was engaged three years later, by Cleofonte Campanini, director of the Chicago opera, as the youngest American premiere danseuse. She made her debut with Galli-Curci in “Traviata” later in 191[?8?]." Evening star. December 18, 1921, Image 83 - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045462/1921-12-18/ed-... "Sylvia Tell, prima ballerina with the San Carlos Grand Opera Company, in Washington this week." The New York herald. September 25, 1921, SECTION FIVE ROTOGRAPHIC SECTION, Image 58 - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83045774/1921-09-25/ed-... "A premiere danseuse who is an American is Sylvia Tell. She is with the San Carlo Opera Company." See also: * Some photos of Sylvia Tell in an album from [https://www.flickr.com/photos/189886292@N04/], whose grandmother was a pupil of Tell at the Cornish School of Fine Arts in Seattle : - www.flickr.com/photos/189886292@N04/albums/72157719490544... * Dancer Sylvia Tell, Seattle, ca. 1925 from Seattle Museum of History & Industry - digitalcollections.lib.washington.edu/digital/collection/...

The date written on the negative is 10/2/17. But the World Series didn't start until 10/6/1917. Buck Weaver played shortstop for the Chicago White Sox, who won the American League Championship in 1917. On 10/1/1917, the White Sox lost a game to the New York Yankees in New York, and according to The Birmingham Age-Herald. October 02, 1917, page 8, col 6, near top, - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85038485/1917-10-02/ed-... the White Sox were to travel back to Chicago on 10/1/1917 evening, stopping at Cleveland. This depicts the Liberty Loan Clock installed on the New York Federal Hall (formerly Treasury Building). The clock was installed as part of the second Liberty Loan Drive in October 1917 (catalog.archives.gov/id/45493130), however despite the scaffolding and band I do not believe the images are taken on the same day. In this image the "New York District Total" is just over $475 million and the "Total US" is around $1.5 billion. As of October 20 $605 million was raised with $60 million in the last day. (New-York tribune. [volume] (New York [N.Y.]), 20 Oct. 1917. Chronicling America: Historic American Newspapers. Lib. of Congress. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1917-10-20/ed-...) so the photo would likely be a few days before October 20, 1917.

Wikipedia entry spells his name without the third "e" en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charles_Sweeny Charles Michael Sweeny (January 26, 1882 – February 27, 1963) was an American soldier of fortune, United States Army lieutenant colonel, French Foreign Legion officer, Polish army brigadier general, Royal Air Force (RAF) group captain, and journalist who fought in numerous conflicts in the 20th century. He recruited fellow Americans to fight in World War II prior to the United States entering the war. See "Captain Charles Sweeny, of Idaho, Tells of Fight for France in Foreign Legion" in the Wallace Miner. July 19, 1917, Page 2 - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85007266/1917-07-19/ed-... "Captain Charles Sweeny, the Idaho man who has won distinction in the French army is writing a series of articles for the Associated Newspapers on the war from the standpoint of the private. He enlisted in the Foreign Legion, an organization that has gained world renown on the west front, was severely wounded, decorated with the highest military honors by the French government for distinguished service, returned to native land to recover from his wounds, entered the service of the United States government with the rank of major and may be called to command the third Idaho regiment if organized by the state." The New York Sun. April 14, 1917, Page 3, col 6, middle - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030431/1917-04-14/ed-... indicates that he had been given permission by the French to return to the U.S. and place himself at his country's service. He was to sail aboard the earliest French liner bound for New York. South Bend news-times., April 24, 1917, EVENING EDITION, page 1, column 7, with headline "FIRST AMERICAN LOANED COUNTRY" - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn87055779/1917-04-24/ed-... indicated in a notice from New York that Sweeny had "just arrived here. So this picture might have been taken in late April 1917.
Ellis Island shows Charles Sweeny of Spokane arriving aboard the Lafayette (nice touch) in 1916. See [https://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/10870805844/]

Could be the same Alice Carpenter as in The photo of her speaking to a crowd of men was used in Biographical Sketch of Alice Carpenter from Biographical Database of Militant Woman Suffragists, 1913-1920 - documents.alexanderstreet.com/d/1009054706 Both dates on the current negative (one on a stamp) appear to indicate that the photo of the four women is from 1916, perhaps in September. Alice Carpenter was clearly an activist. See: * Varied Activities of Women. New York Herald, Sep 10, 1916, Page 27 - www.newspapers.com/article/new-york-herald-varied-activit... Includes photo of Miss Alice Carpenter, chairman of the city committee of the Hughes [Charles Evans Hughes] Alliance "There are some persons born to certain things, and like Mrs. A. Heuston of the Woman Suffrage party, Miss Carpenter was born, among other ends, to lead parades." * Miss Carpenter Leads 15,000 Women into Line for Hughes. New-York Tribune, Aug 20, 1916, Page 13 - www.newspapers.com/article/new-york-tribune-miss-carpente... Includes photo of Miss Alice Carpenter, chairman of the city committee of the Hughes [Charles Evans Hughes] Alliance * A Woman Doctor for Women Investors. New-York Tribune, Aug 04, 1918, Page 46 - www.newspapers.com/article/new-york-tribune-a-woman-docto... Includes photo that is clearly of the same woman as in the Bain photo of the 4 women. "A WOMAN has opened a department for women in the New York office of one of the largest investment houses in the world, with branches in Chicago, Boston, Detroit, Philadelphia, Washington, Paris, London, etc. ... Three years ago on the eighteenth of January the head of the firm sent for Miss Alice Carpenter and said he had reached the conclusion that a department should be opened in which a woman could sell bonds to women investors, explaining to them the elements of finance, giving them the confidence they lacked. And he offered her the position at its head." Interestingly, the name of the investment house is not given. It was William P. Bonbright & Co. See ad at bottom left of New York Times, Nov 17, 1915 ·Page 11 timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1915/11/17/10504742... Success! I've now found this photo, by following the date. Women Leaders of Hughes Alliance, Buffalo Press and Sun-Bulletin, Wed, Sep 13, 1916, Page 1, top, col 4-6. - www.newspapers.com/article/press-and-sun-bulletin-women-l... "These are the leaders of the Women's New York City Committee, of the Hughes' Alliance at their first meeting in New York City. They are, left to right, Belle DeAcosta Green, Alice Carpenter, Catherine Davis and Maude Wetmore." Before finding the picture, I found an article that possibly gives the location: New-York Tribune, Sep 11, 1916, Page 4, Col 5 (near top) www.newspapers.com/article/new-york-tribune-meeting-of-ne... "The Women's City Committee of the Hughes Alliance, Miss Alice Carpenter, chairman. will hold its first big meeting in the Hotel Astor this afternoon at 4:00 o'clock. Miss Carpenter will preside and Philip J. McCook and Dr. Katherine B. Davis will address the women."

The first phonograph was invented in 1877 at the Menlo Park lab. A piece of tin-foil was wrapped around the cylinder in the middle. You shouted a short message into the piece on one side of the cylinder while you turned the handle. www.nps.gov/edis/learn/kidsyouth/the-phonograph.htm

Probably at Yale School of Military Science (in 1916 or 1917). See comments with

As part of its "preparedness" push, Yale organized an Artillery battery in late 1915/early 1916. A January 1916 article in the Cambridge Sentinel reported
Yale has completed its military preparedness by organizing a battery in which nearly five hundred undergraduates have enlisted. It will be equipped with three inch field pieces, which are similar in construction to the famous French 75-millimeter gun. . . .
The battalion (part of the 10th Field Artillery) was activated in June for the Mexican Border crisis. Rather than being sent to Texas, they spend the rest of the summer in Pennsylvania at Camp Tobyhanna. It did not go well. A December article in the Yale Daily News began
The Yale Battalion has passed away. Peace to its ashes! May a loud and long volley of musketry ring out over its grave and may full military honors be accorded the corpse. No one who served with the Batteries last summer is sorry to see the last of them.
The batteries were replaced by a large ROTC program.

At left, en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robert_M._Danford "He was promoted to captain in the Army in 1916." penelope.uchicago.edu/Thayer/E/Gazetteer/Places/America/U... indicates that his promotion to Captain was on June 12, 1916.

The Fargo Forum and Daily Republican. October 05, 1917, page 5, top of col. 1 is probably describing Waldo C. Potter. chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn85042224/1917-10-05/ed-... "CASSELTON MAN MADE MAJOR AT 31 YOUNGEST IN NATION'S ARMY Waldo C. Potter Promoted — Has Been Sent To National Capital -- Unprecedented promotion in U. S. military circles has come to Waldo C. Potter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Franklin C. Potter, prominent Casselton residents, he having within the last few days been given the rank of major. His promotion is from a captaincy and so far as can be learned here, makes him the youngest major in the entire United States service. As major he now becomes a member of the general staff of the war department, and left California last Tuesday for Washington, D. C., in obedience to his new orders. Major Potter, then a captaln with the Fifteenth Field artillery, was sent only two weeks ago from New York on special detail work to Presidio, Cal., and it was while at the latter place that he was notified of his promotion. Last year he was sent to Yale, and spent the winter helping train the students there in military tactics." Moretti, is probably Onorio Moretti, author of "Notes on Training, Field Artillery Details," published in 1917 by Yale University Press. www.google.com/books/edition/Notes_on_Training_Field_Arti... The title page says that Moretti wrote it under the supervision of Danford, and describes them as Asst. Professor and Professor of Military Science at Yale University, respectively, both having formerly been instructors at the School of Fire for Field Artillery at Fort Sill, Oklahoma. So, if Bain and the newspaper reports are correct about the ranks, this picture might have been taken between June 1916 and October 1917 with the names written on the negative at the time. Alternatively, it could have been taken earlier in their military careers, with the names on the negative written during that period.

Given that the next picture in the Bain stream has a neighboring negative number and is identified as at Yale, I suspect this is taken at Yale. Waldo Potter was at Yale with Danford too. See A letter to the Yale Daily News from June 4, 1917 when Potter and Danford were leaving. ydnhistorical.library.yale.edu/?a=d&d=YDN19170604-01.2.8

Harry Primrose, 6th Earl of Rosebery www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q5671733

From www.espncricinfo.com/cricketers/lord-dalmeny-12033 Full name: Albert Edward Harry Mayer Archibald Primrose (Lord Dalmeny) Born -- January 08, 1882, Mayfair, Westminster, London Succeeded as 6th Earl of Rosebery in 1929 Died -- May 30, 1974, Mentmore House, Buckinghamshire, (aged 92y 142d) Extract from obituary in The Cricketer, July 1974 "The Sixth Earl of Rosebery, KT, PC, DSO, Me, who as Lord Dalmeny captained Surrey from 1905 to 1907, died at his home near Leighton Buzzard on May 30. He was 92. A distinguished soldier, administrator and politician (his father was a Liberal Prime Minister), Lord Rosebery was a keen sportsman, and though he will be best remembered as perhaps the major figure of the British Turf in his lifetime, his relatively brief indulgence in county cricket was notable. He had scored 52 for Eton against Harrow in 1900, and at the age of 20 he hit a memorable 197 against MCC. He began playing occasionally for Surrey in 1904 after having played for Buckinghamshire in 1901, twice for Middlesex in 1902, and for Surrey against the Gentlemen of Philadelphia in 1903." I wondered if this last detail means that he actually played cricket in the U.S. But the New-York Tribune. August 07, 1903, Page 5, col 5 (bottom) - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn83030214/1903-08-07/ed-... reports on the match, which was in London. His cap has an "S" -- suggesting that this photo was taken while was playing for Sussex (i.e., probably no later than 1907). He was featured widely in the American newspapers, mainly in the social columns and as a polo player. He is featured in The Saint Paul Globe., November 29, 1903, Page 29, middle of page with portrait, as an eligible bachelor - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn90059523/1903-11-29/ed-... In May 1909, he was married to Dorothy Grosvenor. See the Marion Daily Mirror., May 17, 1909, Page 7, col 4 (top with photo of bride) - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn88077573/1909-05-17/ed-... which says, "It is stated freely In club and society circles that the betrothal of Lord Dalmeny and Miss Grosvenor was 'arranged' by Lord Rosebery In order to keep the Rothschild millions -- the Countess of Rosebery was a Rothschlld -- out of the pretty hands of a stage beauty."

A very similar photograph of Dalmeny appears in the Spaldings Official Cricket Guide for 1907 as part of a writeup of the 1906 Country Cricket season. Same guy, same pose, different location. That photo (credited to Bowden Brothers of London) also served as the basis of the illustration on the cover of Spaldings Official Cricket Guide from 1907 to 1914.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] Terrific find! Meanwhile, the New York Times new source for Sports coverage, The Athletic [ www.nytimes.com/athletic/news/ ] doesn't even include cricket on its list of covered sports!! They don't seem to have noticed that there's some exciting cricket going on on Long Island right now (June 2024 -- www.nassaucountyny.gov/5676/ICC-World-Cup-2024 ). "Fifth Avenue, which the Fifth Avenue Association is pledged to make the street magnificent, was beautified further yesterday by the first appearance of the new police which the association is going to maintain to prevent the overrunning of that thoroughfare by undesirables. Three men went on duty yesterday, and they are the nucleus of a force which in time will number at least 150 patrolmen, under their own officers and having their own headquarters." * Norwich bulletin. May 24, 1912, Page 4, col 6, in 'Other View Points' section - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014086/1912-05-24/ed-... "Frederick the Great's famous grenadiers have a modern counterpart in the new "Fifth avenue special patrol," for the protection and convenience of our latter-day rulers. There are eventually, according to the plan, to be 150 good-looking, tall, soldierly, well-informed men on the new force, but they are not to have special police authority nor the right to make arrests. Outdoor floorwalkers for the fashionable district about describes their status and duties as they concern the public. - Springfield Republican." But the idea appears to have been short-lived. See Daily People, June 21, 1912 (clipping) - www.slp.org/pdf/de_leon/eds1912/jun21_1812.pdf 'Nothing daunted by the finery of the Special Patrol and their artistic poses, the “undesirable” irreverently dubbed the Patrol the “Apollos,” and when the “Apollos” became fresh, the “undesirables” grew fresher.'

The plan might have been to have 150, but they had 3, and by the first week of June they had been arrested for "usurping the functions of the regular police.". By November the mall cops were back on the street, with some adjustments to their uniform. The main sticking point seems to be whether or not they could wear a "shield" (badge). These men's uniforms have reinforces patches to pin a shield on the breast, but nothing pinned there. Badges? We ain't got no badges. We don't need no badges! Norwich Bulletin. December 27, 1912, page 3, right-hand col. under advertisements - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn82014086/1912-12-27/ed-... "Davis Puts Sullivan Away. Buffalo, N. Y Dec. 26. George (One-Round) Davis stopped Jack (Twln) Sullivan here tonight In the third round of a bout scheduled to go ten rounds. Davis will meet the winner of the Willard-Kern bout scheduled to take place In New York tomorrow night." The Bridgeport Evening Farmer. November 16, 1912, Page 7, col 1 - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84022472/1912-11-16/ed-... "Buffalo has a candidate for the heavyweight race in George (One Round) Davis, who has been bowling opponents over with deadly regularity since "debuting" professionally. "One Round's" latest feat was to duplicate "Gunboat Smith's knock-out of Jim Stewart in seven rounds. I understand an attempt will be made to match Davis with the winner of the Wuest-Smith bout." The Bridgeport Evening Farmer. December 12, 1917, Page 8, col 6, near bottom - chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84022472/1917-12-12/ed-... "Willard-Davis Contest. Jess Willard knocked out George ( One Round) Davis ' in the second round at Buffalo, on Dec; ; 12, 1913. The Kansas Cowboy was then climbing the ladder of success - which finally led to his attaining the heavy-weight championship. Davis, the "Fistic Bartender," had an excellent record but he was an easy victim for The Cowboy. Davis earned his name of "One Round" by stopping his men in the initial chapter, but after he began taking on the good fellows, he did not fare so well. He knocked out Jim Stewart the Brooklyn heavyweight, in the seventh round and defeated the veteran Jack (Twin) Sullivan In three rounds, but he was twice knocked out by Soldier Kearns, and Jack Geyer stopped him in one round early in 1914."

Obituary for George W. Jaus is at: www.newspapers.com/article/the-buffalo-news-obituary-for-... He retired in 1953 after 32 years as New York Central Railroad policeman. This means that his boxing career ended ~1921. I suspect that this portrait is from near the beginning of his career, i.e., ~1912. Henry Ware Cattell (1862-1936) American pathologist www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q116025307

On the left is Hyman D. Davis (LOC note spellings). Active in Ohio Republican machine politics, Taft named him as US Marshal for Northern Ohio. I don't think the Senate ever confirmed him but he received annual recess appointments to the post throughout the Taft administration. Emmet Montgomery (Mont) Reilly was also an active Republican machine operative - in his case in Missouri. He was an early Teddy Roosevelt backer and went on to be part of the Warren G. Harding cabal. Harding made him Governor of Puerto Rico. He's gone down in history as one of the worst Governors in the history of Puerto Rico. A photo of Reilly with Roosevelt aboard the K.A.V appears in the June 20, 1910 Bridgeport Evening Farmer. It looks like Mont is wearing the same hat and same watch fob. I'm confident this photo is part of the 18 June 1910 TR's Return to NY series.

Another from the May 1908 public field day at Governors Island. The PFC in front has the daytime signal flags. Behind him (and ready for "night work") is a Colt Acetylene Flash Lantern. The acetylene generator and carbide cannister is not yet connected. The signal flags are NOT semaphore flags (the poles are too long). They are used to send morse code. A long sweep overhead was a dash, a short sweep to one side was a dot. 4 of the 6 soldiers are in Signal Corps Uniform. The 2 on the right are in the uniform of the Coastal Artillery - the one in front showing the insignia of a second class gunner. The tall sergeant in the rear wears the cap insignia and chevrons of a Master Signal Electrician. That flasher is NOT going to malfunction in front of all the VIPs.

No heliograph here, despite the "Tag". As [https://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] says, the displayed device is a signal lantern, specifically a Colt Acetylene Flash lantern, used primarily at night (hence the title at the top of the photograph: "Night Work".). The heliograph used mirrors to reflect sunlight, and were used during the day - there IS a heliograph on display in the accompanying photograph "Day Work", which can be viewed at the Library of Congress, here: www.loc.gov/item/2014680520/ This signal lantern ("Field Lantern" is depicted in Fig. 18 (page 111) of: Manual No. 6, Manual of Visual Signaling of the U.S. Signal Corps, by Captain D. J. Carr, Washington CPO 1905. The heliograph is depicted in Figures 8 & 9 (pp. 76 & 77) of that same manual. There was a Colt Acetylene Flash Lantern on display at the museum at Fort Huachuca, AZ, when I was there last. The 1905 manual gives the brightness of the field lantern as 1,900 candlepower (p. 112), vs. the millions of candlepower from the mirror-reflected sunlight of a heliograph.

[https://www.flickr.com/photos/90124154@N00] Here's a photo of a Colt Acetylene Flash Lantern on display at the Fort Gordon Museum. If you click on the thumbnail image below, then scroll down below the photo to the comments, you'll find links to more information about this device. Much of the material is in this thread: www.treasurebunker.com/forums/index.php?/topic/3804-us-si... [https://www.flickr.com/photos/22360767@N05/16412240452]

The Lebaudy République (later known as La République[1]) was a semi-rigid airship built for the French army in Moisson, France, by sugar manufacturers Lebaudy Frères. She was a sister ship of the Patrie, the main differences between the two being in the dimensions of the gasbag (or 'envelope') and the ballonet.[2][3] Although she was operationally successful, the République crashed in 1909 due to a mechanical failure, killing all four crew members.
According to en.wikipedia.org/wiki/La_R%C3%A9publique_(airship) first flight was on 24 June 1908

The man reclining is a Private First Class in the Signal Corps. He is using the Model 1905 Field Buzzer.  A "buzzer" differed from a telephone in that it could transmit both voice communications (note the microphone in his right hand) and had a "buzzer key" for transmitting morse reliably over bad connections (note the left hand tapping out a message). The metal rod grounds the buzzer

Note it's "Holtzendorff" with a "t". "v" is likely "von" Two possibilities. 1) Arndt von Holtzendorff (age 67) and wife Hermine (58) arrived on the Resolute 2) Alexander and Annemarie von Holtzendorff (53 and 52) arrived on the Albert Ballin. I lean towards the #2. The actual passenger lists are behind a paywall, but an item in The Sun of 31 Dec 26 notes that Arnd von H., a director of the Hamburg American Line was on the Resolute for a round the world cruise. These two don't look dressed for late December.

I was able to find a photograph of this image (the scans are usually made from negatives but occasionally we have photos also). The back says "A. v. Holtzendorff and his American wife". "The Titled Nobility of Europe" lists Alexander's wife's name as Anna, perhaps that's what she commonly went by. It also says they were married in Passaic. I couldn't find a Passaic in Germany, just the one in New Jersey. If he had a wedding in Passaic, it makes me think he was marrying an American woman. I'll see if we can put something like, "probably Alexander and Anne von Holtzendorff".

It looks like they lived in Passaic, New Jersey but they married in Brooklyn in 1897 as Alexander von Holzendorff and Anna M. Haas. I found them in the Passaic, New Jersey directory and in the NYC marriage records. They would have required a passport in 1926, I will see if I can find the passport applications. She may have lost her citizenship if her husband remained a foreign national in 1915 and she would have to reapply. During the first Red Scare the US Supreme Court stripped women of their citizenship who married foreign nationals, and they had to reapply.

From Time Magazine, May 10, 1926
Fonck. Last week burly little Captain Rene Fonck of France, ace of Allied aces, Inspector General of French Aviation, strode down a gangplank in Manhattan and hurried out to Westbury, L. I., to fire questions at Engineer Igor Sikorsky of Russia. The scene of their talk was the Sikorsky airplane factory. The subject was a monster Sikorsky biplane, the S-35, which was being equipped with three 425 h.p. Gnome-Rhone Jupiter motors specially selected abroad and shipped here by Fonck to drive him, without pausing, from Long Island to Paris next autumn in an effort to win a standing prize of $25,000.* A preliminary non-stop flight, Long Island to Halifax and back, was scheduled for early July.

en.wikipedia.org/wiki/René_Fonck 'Colonel René Paul Fonck (27 March 1894 – 18 June 1953) was a French aviator who ended the First World War as the top Entente fighter ace and, when all succeeding aerial conflicts of the 20th and 21st centuries are also considered, Fonck still holds the title of "all-time Allied Ace of Aces".' ... 'During the 1920s, Fonck persuaded Igor Sikorsky to redesign the Sikorsky S-35 for the transatlantic race or Orteig Prize. On 21 September 1926, the aircraft crashed on takeoff when the landing gear collapsed, killing two of his three crew members. Charles Lindbergh won the prize seven months later in 1927.'

The aircraft is a CANT 6 : The CANT 6 was a flying boat designed for Italian military service in 1925. It was a large biplane of conventional design with three engines mounted in nacelles within the interplane gap. Only a single example was produced in its original military configuration, followed by two further aircraft redesigned as 11-seat passenger aircraft. One of these was retained by CANT, but the other entered airline service with Società Italiana Servizi Aerei.

The Marchese Vittorio dei Principi Centurione was an Italian military pilot and seaplane racer. He was killed in a crash in September 1926 while practicing for the Schneider Cup competition. John W. O’Leary, president of the United States Chamber of Commerce at Washington, D. C., formally opened the line by talking to John W. Spangler and Raymond B. Wilcox, presidents of the Chambers of Commerce at Seattle and Portland, Oregon. ... As a preliminary to the opening of this newest trans-continental telephone line, Walter S. Gifford, president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, New York, talked to officials of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company at Seattle and Portland, and then turned the circuit over to Samuel M. Grier, Vice-President of the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company at Washington, who, after greeting Messrs. Spangler and Wilcox at Seattle and Portland, introduced them to Mr. O’Leary." The Belington Progressive. February 10, 1927, page 5, col 1, halfway down, with similar photo, showing two leftmost of the same individuals chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn86092333/1927-02-10/ed-... reports, "The ceremony incident to placing this new line in service was held in the U. S. Chamber of Commerce at Washington with Samuel M. Greer. Vice-President of the Chesapeake and Potomac Telephone Company as master of ceremonies. John W. O'l.eary, President of the U. S. Chamber of Commerce, after being introduced by Mr. Greer made the opening address to John W. Spangler, President of the Seattle Chamber of Commerce and to President Raymond B. Wilcox of the Portland. Oregon, Chamber of Commerce. As a preliminary to the opening of this line W. S. Gifford. President of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company from his office in New York greeted officials of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company at Seattle and Portland, and Vice-President Greer at Washington. With the exchange of greetings completed the circuit was turned over to Mr. Greer." The conclusion seems to be that John W. "Challenge for America’s Cup by Sir Thomas Lipton Would Not Cause a Thrill DEFENSE OF THE TROPHY MEANS WASTE OF MONEY Costs Nearly Million Dollars to Build Craft for Race and Boat Then Is Useless —Windjammers No Longer Popular in United States. BY LAWRENCE PERRY. New YORK. April 6.—Sir Thomas Lipton's arrival in this country for the reported purpose of clearing the ground for a challenge for the America’s cup serves chiefly to remind yachting enthusiasts of the decay of the sport of racing and sailing big windjammers in this country. There is a nautical strain in the American blood which will never be eliminated, and its effects are seen in the clouds of racing sailboats of the smaller classes that beautify the bays and rivers of the Atlantic Seaboard, the inland lakes of the Middle West and Pacific Coast waters. But when it comes to the canvas-propelled leviathans which used to dominate the regattas of the New York Yacht Club there is a different story. With few exceptions the largest sloops now are of 40-foot water-line length, while schooners do not exceed 70 feet. And there are few enough of those."

Thomas Lipton did manage to get one more challenge accepted after 1926, but the next America's Cup was not until 1930. The 1930 race and a few subsequent ones used J-class boats. See en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J_Class_(yacht) en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Shamrock_V The boat built by Camper and Nicholson for Lipton for the 1930 race, was still in use and available for charter until very recently. Here she was in 2009: In June 2023, she was having a refit. See www.boatinternational.com/yachts/news/shamrock-v-yacht-re...

I have absolutely no idea who S.J. Marsh is or why the Bain boys wanted his picture. What's interesting is his uniform. It's vaguely American WWI doughboy, with the Sam Brown belt and campaign hat. But the chain mail epaulettes with British style rank pips, the cavalry gauntlets and riding crop, and physique that says "doughy" more than "doughboy" raise some alarm bells. Zooming in shows that the buttons on his uniform have an LF. Likewise the collar tabs and (as near as I can tell) the insignia on his campaign hat. He's wearing the uniform of the Legion of Frontiersmen; a militia group set up to take advantage of the special skills some colonial Englishmen developed in the far reaches of the Empire. Sort of Rough Riders for the British Empire For comparison, see [https://www.flickr.com/photos/14684508@N02/6534691857/]

TUNIC – Dark blue serge with Standing collar, traditional, 5 buttons down front, one button on each breast pocket and two buttons on each sleeve at cuff on outside seam has been the standard. Although Open Neck collar may have been permissible, complete uniformity within a unit must be observed. In practice the Standing collar tunic has been the expected norm in Canada
from frontiersmenhistorian.files.wordpress.com/2019/07/lf-legi... Another note I read stated that the early uniform tunics could be either dark blue or black, but with the rise of Mussolini they eliminated the black option.

Courtland Hunter Young Jr. (1876-1930) www.wikidata.org/wiki/Q69694939

The happy couple between divorce trials. Courtland Hunter Young was a wealthy magazine publisher. "Wife" refers to Dorothy Rosabelle Campbell Young, formerly of "the follies". They were in and out of the papers in the 20s due to their messy love life. They married in 1920 (she was a 19 yr old actress) and he was a 44 yr old publishing tycoon. In 1923 she sued for "separation" citing cruelty and drunkenness. He sued for divorce. That fell apart when the Judge threatened that if they didn't reconcile he would take custody of their daughter from both them. In September 1926 Courtland again sued for divorce, still claiming infidelity and denying paternity of their son born in 1924. When the case went to trial in 1927 he claimed that her "jazzmania" led her to a "high, fast life." Divorce granted 1928. "The oscillation of this plantiff and defendant between the closest intimacy land legal warfare has been so continuous,” wrote Justice Proskauer, "That I think it may be fairly said that the plaintiff makes out a prima facie case in this action for separation" Ellis Island records don't show Courtland Young ever passing through immigration, but they do show a 26 year old Dorothy Young arriving on the Cameronia in 1926. Maybe he's welcoming her home after a visit to her mother? I'm sure there's no connection between her return to America and the mourning armband he's wearing. A trivial speculation . . . His daughter's name was Rosebud. Courtland the publshing magnate died alone in a fire in his apartment in 1930. He may or may not have been sober. I only imagine his last words were "Rosebud".
